symptoms.name: Gummatous ulcers
symptoms.pattern: Typically manifests after 2 years of life; tends to involve nose, septum, and hard palate

symptoms.name: Periosteal lesions
symptoms.pattern: Results in saber shins and bossing of frontal and parietal bones

symptoms.name: Neurosyphilis
symptoms.pattern: May develop into juvenile paresis and tabes

symptoms.name: Interstitial keratitis
symptoms.pattern: Most common eye lesion; frequently recurs, often resulting in corneal scarring

symptoms.name: Sensorineural deafness
symptoms.pattern: Often progressive; may appear at any age

symptoms.name: Maldevelopment of maxilla
symptoms.pattern: Results in “bulldog” facies; characteristic, if infrequent, sequelae

physical_findings: Periosteal lesions (saber shins, bossing of frontal and parietal bones)
risk_factors: Untreated primary or secondary syphilis in the mother

x-rays (long bones): Wimberger sign (symmetric erosions of the upper tibia)
Excessive callus formation at the ends of long bones

required: Serologic testing of mother and child
supportive: Microscopic visualization of spirochetes (in samples from lesions)
